questions.text: May-Thurner syndrome involves?
questions.solution:
May-Thurner syndrome involves left iliac vein compression.

At the site where the right iliac artery crosses over the left iliac vein, the left iliac vein may become chronically narrowed predisposing to iliofemoral venous thrombosis. This is called May-Thurner syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) does not take up radioactive iodine as MTC is TSH-independent.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular (C cells) derived from the neural crest. Histological analysis shows characteristic amyloid stroma. High levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced by many medullary tumors. It also secretes 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) or prostaglandin which may be a reason for diarrhea in 30% of cases. 20% are familial (multicentric and bilateral) and seen in younger ages. 80% sporadic (originate in one lobe) and is seen in the 6th decade. It is diagnosed by FNAC.

Treatment includes total thyroidectomy plus elective dissection of the central neck nodes plus or minus ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (if neck node positive). If nodal metastasis cure is unlikely, the gross disease should be removed.

Related Pearl: Secretion of medullary thyroid tumors

Medullary thyroid tumor secrete the following:

  • Calcitonin
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Calcitonin gene–related peptide
  • Histaminadases
  • Prostaglandins E 2 and F 2 α
  • Serotonin

Calcitonin and serotonins are responsible for diarrhea in MTC.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency in an unconscious state. On examination his heart rate is 120 bpm, BP is 70/50mmHg and pupils are reactive. Which of the following positions will help improve the blood pressure of the patient?
questions.solution:
A patient with hypotension must immediately be put in the Trendelenberg position as this would increase the venous return to the heart and thus improve the cardiac output. 

Trendelenberg position is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed is put into an incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)

It is commonly used while performing pelvic procedures as well as resuscitating a patient in shock.

Safety measures to be employed while the patient is in this position include :

  • The safety belt is positioned at a height of 5 cm above the knee, ensuring that it is never placed over the abdomen, in order to prevent the patient from slipping off the table.
  • Shoulder supports are employed in cases where the Trendelenburg position is required.
  • In order to mitigate the risk of lateral displacement of the patient, it is imperative to have side supports in place when tilting the table laterally.

The adoption of a steep Trendelenburg posture has been seen to potentially lead to respiratory compromise, as well as an increase in intracranial and intraocular pressure.

Other options

Option A: Jackknife position is a modified prone position where the patient's hips are supported on a pillow and the table is flexed at a 90-degree angle with the head and feet at a lower level. It is not used anymore due to the chest compression causing impaired ventilation leading to positional asphyxia. It was used for hemorrhoids and fissure surgery. Making the patient assume this position during a suspected shock is not advisable.

Option B: If an air embolism is suspected, the patient should immediately be placed into a left lateral decubitus Trendelenburg position. This allows the entrapped air to be stabilized within the right ventricle.

Option C: Semi-fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions and for patients with a nasogastric tube. This position would further reduce the venous return and is therefore not preferred.

questions.text: A 28-year-old school teacher suffers a road traffic accident that results in a head injury. She undergoes a decompressive craniectomy following which she recovers and is now able to function independently. She returns to work as a teacher, but acknowledges that her capacity is not as before. Her recovery would be given a score of _______ as per the Glasgow outcome score.
questions.solution:
Since she is independent and has returned to work, she would be given a score of 5, corresponding to a good recovery. Good recovery implies independence and the potential to return to work rather than a complete return to previous capacity.

The Glasgow outcome score is used to quantify the degree of recovery achieved after a head injury.

Functional status Score
Good recovery 5
Moderate disability 4
Severe disability 3
Persistent vegetative state 2
Dead 1

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker was incidentally discovered with asymptomatic, red velvety lesions on the soft palate during a dental examination. The histopathological report confirmed the diagnosis of erythroplakia. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
As erythroplakia is associated with a high risk of malignancy, it is treated with surgical excision.

Erythroplakia is a premalignant lesion of the oral mucosa that appears as a bright red velvety plaque. All erythroplakia and speckled leucoplakia should undergo urgent incisional biopsy, as they have a high risk of malignant transformation. Biopsy must be taken from multiple areas within the lesion.

Management includes the elimination of associated aetiological factors (smoking, areca nut/pan habit, alcohol consumption) and surgical excision of the lesion. Currently, there are no successful chemoprevention agents.

Oral lesions associated with malignant transformation are as follows:

  • High-risk lesions
    • Erythroplakia (homogenous or speckled)
    • Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia
    • Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis
  • Medium-risk lesions
    • Oral submucous fibrosis
    • Syphilitic glossitis
  • Low-risk/equivocal-risk lesions
    • Oral lichen planus
    • Discoid lupus erythematosus
    • Discoid keratosis congenita

questions.text: A surgeon working in a community health centre notices that the following suture material shown in the image is the only suture available in stock for use. In which of the following conditions is this suture material not useful?
questions.solution:
The suture material shown in the image is plain catgut which is a yellowish absorbable suture material and cannot be used in procedures like hernia repair that require prolonged support.

Plain catgut:

  • It is made of collagen derived from healthy sheep or cattle. 
  • It is absorbed by Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 7–10 days.
  • It is used to ligate superficial vessels, suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas, and other tissues that heal rapidly. The tensile strength is lost within 7–10 days and shows marked patient variability.

Contraindications: Not for use in tissues that heal slowly and require prolonged support. Synthetic absorbable sutures are superior in this case.

questions.text:
Given below are colors representing the various intravenous cannulae. Arrange them in increasing order of their size.

1. Pink 
2. Grey
3. Green
4. Orange
5. Blue
questions.solution:
The increasing order of size for the given cannulae is 5, 1, 3, 2, and 4.          

  • 5 (22G) - Blue
  • 1 (20G) - Pink
  • 3 (18G) - Green
  • 2 (16G) - Grey
  • 4 (14G) - Orange

A standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. It refers to the number of wires of the same size as the cannula that could pass through a hole of a standard size in parallel. Therefore larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

questions.text: In surgical management of pneumothorax, one of the objectives is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain subsequent leaks and prevent complete lung collapse. Pleural adhesion cannot be achieved in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Pleural adhesion cannot be achieved by pleural diathermy.

Diathermy is a surgical method that uses electrical energy in a controlled manner, causing targeted thermal damage to tissues.

Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or as an open procedure (thoracotomy). One of the objectives is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain subsequent leaks and prevent complete lung collapse.

Pleural adhesion is achieved in one of three ways:

  • Pleurectomy: systematically stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall.
  • Pleural abrasion: a scourer is used to scrape off the slick surface of the parietal pleura.
  • Chemical pleurodesis: usually talc is used and is insufflated into the chest cavity.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. What would be the initial management in this case?
questions.solution:
The initial management of a patient presenting with Stanford type B aortic dissection is the administration of anti-hypertensives.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear and most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients. Clinically, patients present with tearing intrascapular pain.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified in two ways: the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, and the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of the aorta Type II Type A

Descending aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Imaging: 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta. 

Treatment options:

Ascending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.

Descending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type B (DeBakey Type III) is initially best managed nonoperatively by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is diagnosed with lymph node-positive, early invasive breast cancer. IHC reveals ER +, PR +, and HER-2-neu 1+. Which of the following adjuvant treatment will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests early invasive breast cancer in a pre-menopausal woman, which is lymph node-positive, hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR +), and Her-2/neu negative (Her-2/neu IHC score of 1+ is considered negative). Hence, Chemotherapy + Tamoxifen is the adjuvant treatment of choice. 

Treatment of early-stage breast cancer (T1-2 N0-1 M0) includes:

Breast conservation surgery (BCS) + ALND or SLNB + Radiotherapy
  • BCS is followed by radiotherapy
  • Mastectomy is done if BCS is contraindicated.
  • Clinical N0 status-sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) at the time of surgery.
  • Clinical N1 status-ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA): axillary lymph node dissection (ALND) if positive and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) if negative.
Endocrine therapy: for hormone receptor (ER/PR) positive 
  • For Premenopausal women-tamoxifen (selective estrogen receptor modulator, SERM)
  • For post-menopausal women (usually >50 years)-anastrozole (Aromatase inhibitor)
  • Tamoxifen has an agonistic action on the endometrium, leading to an increased risk of endometrial cancers Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women.

Anti-Her-2 therapy: for Her-2/neu positive breast cancer
  • Trastuzumab is given
  • Her-2/neu IHC interpretation:
  •   0 or 1+ = Negative
  •   2+ = Equivocal cases ->        confirmed with Fluorescence    in situ hybridization (FISH)      analysis
  •   3+ = Positive
Chemotherapy

Indicated for:

  • Lymph nodes positive
  • Lymph nodes negative but tumor size of >1 cm
  • Lymph nodes negative and tumor size of >0.5 cm with
    • Blood vessel/Lymph vessel invasion
    • ER/PR –ve
    • Her-2/neu overexpression
    • High grade
  • Triple-negative breast carcinoma
  • High recurrence score after Oncotype Dx

The table below shows the summary of the adjuvant treatment approach:

  Tumor hormone receptor status (ER, PR)
Tumor HER status Positive Negative
Positive Endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab Chemotherapy + trastuzumab
Negative Endocrine therapy ± chemotherapy Chemotherapy

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with carcinoma of the tongue has a defect of more than 2 cm.  The patient is planned for hemiglossectomy and tongue reconstruction using a radial forearm flap. The surgeon plans to use the following approach. What is this procedure/ approach called?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the visor approach (like the visor of the helmet). It provides excellent access to the floor of the mouth and tongue. 

In the Visor approach, an incision is made in the cervical crease from the mastoid to the mastoid. Another incision is made in the lingual gingival sulcus from one posterior molar to the other side posterior molar. This frees the skin which is present over the chin and floor of the mouth. This flap is elevated like a visor of the helmet providing a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the disadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).

The lip-split (Option A) and paramedian/ median mandibulotomy approaches are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal cancers. Lip-split mandibulotomy is the most commonly used access procedure. It provides better access to posterior oral cavity, base of tongue, and oropharynx.

Trans-oral wedge resection (Option C) is done for moderate-sized anterior oral tumors.

Commando operation (Option D) is combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection, and it is used mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fever and painful enlargement of her thyroid gland. She also gives a history of having an upper respiratory tract infection(URTI) 2 days ago. A biopsy of the thyroid gland showed findings as seen in the image below. What is the next step of management in this case?

choices.text: Follow up with anti TPO antibodies once in three months
Conservative management with steroids and NSAIDs

questions.solution:
The painful enlargement of the thyroid gland with a history of URTI and the histopathology showing granulomatous inflammation in the thyroid gland are suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis which is managed by steroids and NSAIDs.

Granulomatous/DeQuervain’s thyroiditis may follow a viral infection. In a typical subacute presentation, there is a painful, firm, and irregular enlargement of the thyroid gland, fever, and malaise. There may be raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, serum T4 may be high normal, or slightly raised, and I123 uptake of the gland is low.

It is an inflammatory condition and not an infection as the thyroid gland is inherently resistant to infection due to its extensive blood and lymphatic supply, high iodide content, and fibrous capsule.  It is characterized by an inflammatory infiltrate leading to an initial hyperthyroid phase due to follicular destruction followed by a hypothyroid phase due to thyroid hormone depletion.

Microscopy shows aggregates of lymphocytes, epitheloid cells, activated macrophages, and plasma cells, associated with collapsed and damaged thyroid follicles. Multinucleate giant cells can be seen.

It is a self-limited disease as the immune response is virus-initiated. The specific treatment for acute cases with severe pain is to give prednisone 10-20 mg daily for 7 days and to gradually taper over the next month. If thyroid failure is prominent, treatment with thyroxine may be required until function recovers.

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: A surgeon while performing an abdominal incision uses the surgical blade that is shown in the figure. What is the size of this surgical blade?
questions.solution:
The size of the surgical blade shown is 22. It is often used for abdominal incisions.

The number 10 is used for skin incisions.

The number 11 is often used for drain insertion and arteriotomy. These blades have a sharp tip. 

The number 15 is often used for minor surgical procedures.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the following findings on his right lower limbs. Following examination, he is diagnosed to have perforator incompetence. Which of the following tests can help make this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fegan’s test is used to detect perforator incompetence.

The following table gives the tests and the conditions they help to detect:

TEST CONDITION
Fegan's test Perforator incompetence

Brodie Trendelenburg test

  • Part I
  • Part II

 

Saphenofemoral incompetence
Perforator incompetence
Morrissey's cough impulse test Saphenofemoral valve incompetence
Modified Perthe's test Deep venous thrombosis (DVT)

 

Fegan’s test - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.

Brodie Trendelenburg test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:

  • Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows saphenofemoral incompetence.
  • Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.

Morrissey’s cough impulse test - The limb is elevated to empty the varicose veins and then lowered to the bed. The patient is asked to cough forcibly. An expansile cough impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if the saphenofemoral valve is incompetent. Similarly, a bruit may be heard on auscultation. The patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates saphenofemoral valve incompetence.

Modified Perthe’s test - A tourniquet is tied around the upper part of the thigh to prevent reflux down the vein and the patient is asked to walk around. The varicose veins will shrink in the presence of normal communicating and deep veins. If there is any block, the veins will get more distended. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with Warthin's tumour is posted for submandibular gland excision. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured during this procedure?
questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve is injured during submandibular gland resection among the given options.

Nerves at risk for injury during removal of the submandibular gland include:

  1. Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve
  2. Lingual nerve
  3. Hypoglossal nerve

An important landmark in submandibular gland dissection is the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Once identified, it can be retracted forward to reveal the deep lobe of the gland. The gland is then retracted inferiorly, invariably attached to the lingual nerve through parasympathetic secretor motor fibres. The hypoglossal nerves lie deep in the submandibular capsule and should not be damaged during intracapsular dissection.

Complications of submandibular gland resection:

  • Haematoma
  • Wound infection
  • Marginal mandibular nerve injury
  • Lingual nerve injury
  • Hypoglossal nerve injury
  • Transection of the nerve to the mylohyoid muscle producing submental skin anaesthesia

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with fever & pain in her left breast, which appears as below. On examination of the affected side, there is local warmth,  point tenderness over the dependent area, and a positive fluctuation test. There is no palpable lump or skin thinning. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side. The contralateral breast is normal. What is the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and Drainage after confirming with an ultrasound
Broad spectrum antibiotics only  after confirming with an ultrasound
Aspiration under USG guidance and antibiotics - Repeated aspiration if necessary
Punch biopsy under ultrasound guidance followed by a course of IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscess.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

The below table summarises likely features to differentiate Bacterial mastitis from a Breast abscess

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation
due to ascending infection 
or infection due to milk stasis 		 Occurs as a complication of mastitis
Pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness
Erythema		 Point tenderness
Erythema
Induration of skin(if chronic)
Lymphadenopathy
Fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics
Antibiotics		 Analgesic
Aspiration of Pus
Antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who is a chronic smoker presented to the hospital with intermittent claudication pain in the left thigh and calf region while walking to the bathroom. Which of the following arteries is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has pain in the left thigh and calf region suggesting an arterial disease, and the muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease, the affected vessel is the left iliac artery.

Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery. Aortoiliac disease affects the infrarenal aorta and iliac arteries.

Management involves smoking cessation, lifestyle modifications, and treatment of underlying diabetes or hyperlipidemia if present.

For claudication, cilostazol or pentoxyfilline is used. Cilostazol is superior to pentoxyfilline. 

Surgical options include aortoiliac bypass, aortobifemoral bypass, percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA), which can be with or without stent placement, and thromboendarterectomy.

The following table shows the correlation of clinical findings to the site of disease:

Bruit over the aortoiliac region

Absence of femoral and distal pulses

Claudication of thigh and calf, unilaterally

Bruit over iliac region

Absence of femoral and distal pulses

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with the following after an episode of sore throat. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Gurgling sound is produced on pressing the swelling
Managed conservatively with antibiotics and observation
The swelling increases in size on Valsalva manuever

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst. It moves upwards while swallowing and protrusion of the tongue.

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection.

Thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. 

It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct:

    • Infrahyoid (most common site)
    • Region of thyroid cartilage
    • Suprahyoid
    • Floor of mouth
    • Beneath foramen caecum


Clinical features- Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. The swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant. The thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in normal location.

Complications of thyroglossal cyst:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%).

Neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis 
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

Features of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Dyball retractor.

Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

Option B: The below image is that of a Langenbeck retractor. It is used for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. 

Option C: Goligher retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and the upper end of abdomino-perineal resection. The retractor is inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel away from the operation site.

Option D: Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for intermediate-type operations, such as:

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the fluid given in the image below?

choices.text: Used in treatment of increased intracranial pressure.
Hyperchloremic metabolic alkalosis is a possible side effect.
Serum sodium levels should be monitored at regular intervals during its administration.
Concentration of solute is higher compared to plasma and interstitial fluid.

questions.solution:
The fluid shown in the image is hypertonic saline (HS) and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis is a possible side effect of the administration of HS(not hyperchloremic metabolic alkalosis).

Hypertonic saline is a crystalloid intravenous fluid. It contains sodium chloride dissolved in water with a higher sodium concentration. It has a higher concentration of solute compared to plasma and interstitial fluid

3% and 5% HS is used in the treatment of hyponatremia and increased intracranial pressure. It increases the osmolarity of the blood which shifts the fluid from the extravascular space to the intravascular space. This decreases brain edema and reduces intracranial pressure.

Less volume of HS administration is required to achieve similar plasma volumes as compared to large volumes of normal saline. It also stimulates the release of vasopressin from the pituitary gland, which decreases water loss through the kidneys. Serum sodium and potassium levels should be monitored regularly.  

The most common adverse effects are related to the route of administration such as infection of the IV site, and thrombophlebitis. Due to the addition of NaCl, administration of HS can result in hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. Rapid correction of severe hyponatremia can result in osmotic demyelination syndrome.

HS should be administered carefully in patients with congestive heart failure or renal insufficiency due to their already increased fluid and sodium loads. Serum sodium levels should be monitored regularly when a bolus of HS is used in the correction of hyponatremia.

questions.text: What is the correct order of the normal phases of wound healing?

choices.text: Remodeling phase > Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase
Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Remodeling phase > Proliferative phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase

questions.solution:
The correct order of the normal phases of wound healing is the hemostatic phase > inflammatory phase > proliferative phase > remodeling phase.

The inflammatory phase begins immediately after wounding and lasts 2-3 days. Bleeding is followed by vasoconstriction and thrombus formation to limit blood loss. Occasionally, the early part of the inflammatory phase is called the hemostatic phase.

The proliferative phase lasts from the 3rd day to the 3rd week consisting mainly of fibroblast activity with the production of collagen and ground substance, growth of new blood vessels, and re-epithelialization of the wound surface.

The remodeling phase is characterized by maturation of collagen- type 1 replacing type 3 until a ratio of 4:1 is achieved. The mature collagen leads to increased tensile strength and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: A patient presents with a right breast lump of size 4 cm x 5 cm. Physical examination of the breast reveals dimpling of the breast with erythema occupying half her breast surface. She states that her condition rapidly progressed in the last 3 months. On the right side, fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes are palpable. Biopsy reveals invasive carcinoma.  There is no evidence of distant metastasis. Which of the following represents this patient's TNM staging.
questions.solution:
The patient described in this case meets the diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer and hence her TNM staging is T4d N3b M0

  • Inflammatory breast cancer is classified as T4d irrespective of tumor size: T4d
  • Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph node involvement: N3b
  • Lack of distant metastasis: M0
  • Therefore, the staging is T4d N3b M0.

The diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer is - 

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema and/or peau d’orange, and/or warm breast, with or without an underlying palpable mass

  • Duration of history no more than six months.

  • Erythema occupying at least one-third of the breast.

  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma. 

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0

No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
M0 Metastasis absent
M1 Metastasis present

 

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text:
Which of the following procedure is helpful in the management of a patient with a recurrent BCC near the right eye?

MOHS- Microscopically Oriented Histographic Surgery
questions.solution:
For a case of recurrent basal cell carcinoma located near the eye, MOHS (Microscopically Oriented Histographic Surgery) is preferred. 

Mohs’ microscopic surgery/MOHS involves a process of initial surgical excision of the tumor, followed by repeated tissue sampling along lateral and deep margins. This procedure attains a high rate of local tumor control through the use of horizontal frozen sections. These tissue samples are examined immediately under frozen section control for evidence of tumor. This process is repeated until the clearance is finally obtained.

MMS is preferred in:

  • Recurrent tumors
  • High-risk tumors
  • Primaries with perineural invasion
  • Lesions with diameters >2 cm
  • Poorly differentiated lesions
  • Tumors with irregular margins
  • Tumors in anatomic areas such as the eye, nose, mouth, and ear, where tissue preservation is important.

BCC is a slow-growing, locally invasive, malignant tumor of epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis and hair follicles. Despite its high prevalence, there is an extremely rare occurrence of metastases. Mutation in the hedgehog signaling pathway is associated with basal cell carcinoma. 

Management of BCC can be surgical or non-surgical.

  • Non-surgical
     
    • It is radiosensitive. If the lesion is away from the vital structure (like away from the eyes), then curative radiotherapy can be given. Radiotherapy is not given, once it erodes cartilage or bone. RT is not given to the BCC of the ear and is close to lacrimal canaliculi.
    • The small molecule inhibitor of the hedgehog pathway vismodegib maybe be used.

  • Surgical

    • Wide excision (1 cm clearance) with skin grafting, primary suturing, or flap (Z plasty, rhomboid flap, rotation flap) is the procedure of choice.
    • Laser surgery, photodynamic therapy, 5 fluorouracil local application.
    • Cryosurgery.
    • MOHS (Microscopically Oriented Histographic Surgery)- useful in conditions like BCC close to eyes, nose, or ear, to preserve more tissue

questions.text: A 36-year-old type 1 diabetic female presents with neck swelling, decreased appetite and weight gain. Lab investigations reveal raised TSH, low T3 and anti-thyroglobulin antibody positive. FNAC is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points toward autoimmune thyroiditis in the hypothyroid phase. Histopathology shows diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid tissue. Positive thyroglobulin antibodies are together suggestive of autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis/ Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (also known as Struma Lymphamatosa).

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is an auto-immune disorder in which the antibodies are directed against thyroid peroxidase enzyme, thyroglobulin molecule and other microsomal enzymes. This condition is usually associated with other autoimmune disorders like type I diabetes, vitiligo, myasthenia gravis and pernicious anaemia.

Patient presents with painless diffuse thyroid swelling with a rubbery consistency most often giving a bosselated appearance. This condition initially presents with features of hyperthyroidism (Hashitoxicosis) for a transient period due to the destruction of follicles and the inflammatory process but most commonly, patients present with hypothyroid features. Lab values reveal increased TSH, low T3, T4, and thyroid autoantibodies.

Histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells or Askanazy cells.

Long-standing cases have a high chance of developing into malignant lymphoma or papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

 

Clinical features

 Histology
Dequervains’ thyroiditis (Option A)
  • Viral aetiology either mumps or coxsackie viruses
  • Presents as a painful goitre
 Inflammatory response with infiltration of lymphocytes, neutrophils, multinucleated giant cells 
Grave’s disease (Option C)
  • Autoimmune disease with increased levels of TSH receptor antibodies.
  • Presents with diffuse goitre, thyrotoxicosis features and autoimmune manifestations.
 Acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with absence of normal colloid in the tall columnar epithelium.
Reidel’s thyroiditis (Option D)
  • Presents as swelling with irregular surface, stony hard consistency and stridor.
  • Positive Berry’s sign (absence/impalpable carotid pulsation)
  • Small goitre. 
 Fibrous tissue infiltrates the capsule into surrounding muscles, paratracheal tissues, and carotid sheath. (‘Woody Thyroiditis’, ‘Ligneous Thyroiditis’). 

The histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is shown below:

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in some autoimmune thyroid disorders

Antibody Disorder
TSH receptor-stimulating Immunoglobulins (TSI) Graves disease
Anti TPO & Anti Tg antibodies Chronic lymphocytic(Hashimoto) thyroiditis

TRBAb

(maternal transmission)

 Transient congenital hypothyroidism (maternal autoimmune thyroid disease)
  • Anti TPO – Anti thyroperoxidase antibody
  • Anti Tg – Antithyroglobulin antibody
  • TRBAb – TSH receptor blocking antibodies

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: Which of the following is against the principles for the use of antibiotic therapy in surgical infection?

choices.text: Antibiotics do not replace surgical drainage of infection
Only spreading infection or sytemic infection justify use of antibiotics
Pus for culture should be taken after antibiotic cover is started

questions.solution:
Pus for culture should be taken before antibiotic cover is started.

Principles for the use of antibiotic therapy:

  • Surgical drainage of infection cannot be replaced by antibiotics. 
  • The use of antibiotics is justified only if spreading infections or signs of systemic infection are present.
  • The organism and sensitivity should be determined.
  • Tissue or pus culture should be taken before antibiotic cover is started.

questions.text:
Match the following flaps with their blood supply:
1. Pectoralis major a. Thoracodorsal artery
2. Temporalis b. Superficial temporal artery
3. Temporoparietal fascia c. Deep temporal artery
4. Latissimus dorsi d. Internal mammary artery
5. Deltopectoral flap e. Thoracoacromial artery
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d.

A surgical flap is used to transfer tissue with its blood supply, from a donor area, to reconstruct a defect in the recipient artery. A flap is composed of a base, pedicle, and tip, and the pedicle contains the blood supply. 

The flaps and their blood supply are given in the following table:

FLAP  BLOOD SUPPLY
Pectoralis major Pectoral branch of thoracoacromial artery
Temporalis Deep temporal artery
Temporoparietal fascia Superficial temporal artery
Latissimus dorsi Thoracodorsal artery
Deltopectoral flap Intercostal perforators of internal mammary artery

The image given below shows the pectoralis major myocutaneous flap and latissimus dorsi flap.

questions.text: The false statement about cystic masses of the neck is:

choices.text: Branchial cyst arises from the second pharyngeal pouch
Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph
Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion
Fluctuation is positive in branchial cyst

questions.solution:
Branchial cyst does not arise from the second pharyngeal pouch. 

The branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. The squamous epithelium lines the cyst and contains thick, turbid fluid of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate. The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial fistulas may be congenital or acquired. The external orifice of the congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid and the internal orifice is present on the anterior aspect of the posterior faucial pillar. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete excision for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

Treatment is complete excision of the cyst or fistula to avoid recurrence.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Cystic hygroma is a cystic swelling due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac. It usually presents in the early infancy or at birth which may obstruct labor. The cyst contains clear lymph and is lined by a single layer of epithelium with a mosaic appearance. The swelling may involve parotid, submandibular, tongue and floor of mouth areas. It is soft and compressible which increases in size when the child coughs or cries. It is characterised by its brilliant transillumination capacity. 

Complete excision of the cyst is the definitive treatment. An alternative treatment is the injection of a sclerosing agent. Tracheostomy is required if the cyst expands rapidly and causes respiratory distress.

Below is an image showing a child with cystic hygroma.

Thyroglossal cysts are persistent thyroglossal duct tracts and thus can be found anywhere along or adjacent to the midline from the base of tongue to the thyroid isthmus. The cyst moves upwards while swallowing or on tongue protrusion. It can become infected or spontaneously rupture presenting as a discharging sinus on the skin of the neck. 

Definitive treatment is the Sistrunk operation where complete excision of the tract along with the body of the hyoid.

Below is the image of a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with swelling, pain, and heaviness in her left leg. A duplex scan showed saphenofemoral incompetence and a normal perforator. Which of the following has no role in the management options?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of swelling, pain, and heaviness in the leg along with duplex scan findings of saphenofemoral incompetence suggests varicose veins. Injection sclerotherapy has no role in the management of saphenofemoral incompetence. It is mainly indicated for thread veins or dermal flares (<1 mm in diameter), and for recurrent varicosities.

Varicose veins are subcutaneous dilated, tortuous veins 3mm or more in diameter. Clinical features include dragging pain, heaviness in legs, itching, burning, swelling of feet, discoloration, ulceration, etc.

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for varicose veins.

The management of varicose veins is as follows:

Incompetence Management
Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral (SFJ) 
  • Endothermal ablation (gold standard treatment for varicose veins). It includes:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
  • Trendelenburg procedure (Flush Ligation of Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) after ligation of 6 tributaries) ± stripping (retrogradely up to the knee, to prevent saphenous nerve injury.)     
Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal (SPJ)
  • Flush ligation of SPJ (Stripping is not done to prevent sural nerve injury)
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)
Perforator 
  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfascial ligations
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS) - smaller incision, so cosmetically better
  • Endothermal ablation:
  • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA)

New treatment modalities:

  • Foam sclerotherapy - The Tessari method is a widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy. Sclerosant: air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4
  • Endovenous glue therapy - endoluminal application of cyanoacrylate adhesive 
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

Other options :
Injection sclerotherapy -  injecting a sclerosing agent directly into the superficial veins. The most commonly used sclerosant is sodium tetradecyl sulfate.

The indications and contraindications of injection sclerotherapy are as follows:

Indications   Contraindications
  • Uncomplicated perforator incompetence
  • Smaller varices—reticular veins, thread veins (telangiectasis)
  • Recurrent varices
  • Isolated varicosities
  • Aged/unfit patients
  • Saphenofemoral incompetence 
  • Huge varicosities
  • Peripheral arterial diseases 
  • Deep venous thrombosis 
  • Hypersensitivity

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

C1

C2

C3

C4

to chronic venous disease

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

C6

C6r

S

A

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Esi

Anatomic classification (A)

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding the management of breast cancer is NOT true?

choices.text: Mammaprint and Oncotype Dx are scores used in early breast cancer to predict the benefit of chemotherapy
Oncotype Dx is a 21 gene assay which can be used in ER positive and node-negative patients
Mammaprint is a 70 gene assay which can be used in ER, PR negative patients only
There is more data to support the use of Oncotype Dx

questions.solution:
Mammaprint is a multigene (70 gene) assay used for risk assessment in patients with ER-positive or ER-negative tumors.

Oncotype DX and Mammaprint are tumor genomic assays i.e. they assess expression of various genes in the given sample of breast tissue and thus help in determining the selection of patients for systemic treat­ment (e.g., chemotherapy, endocrine therapy) and predict the response of patients to these pharmacologic treatments. They also help in detecting the likelihood of recurrence.

Oncotype DX

  • 21 gene assay
  • Used for T1, and T2 tumors which are node-negative and ER-positive.
  • Used to assess whether patients with these tumors will benefit from chemotherapy.
  • The Oncotype DX test analyzes the activity of 21 genes and then calculates a recurrence score number between 0 and 100; the higher the score, the greater the risk of recurrence.
  • TAILORx trial and other trials support the use of Oncotype Dx

MammaPrint test

  • 70 gene assay
  • Used for T1, and T2 tumors which are node-negative but can either be ER-positive or negative
  • The MammaPrint test isn’t included in the NCCN and ASCO treatment guidelines.

Of the genomic tests used on breast cancer, the Oncotype DX test has the most thorough data supporting its use to make treatment decisions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a lump in her right breast, and she was advised to undergo a mammogram. The radiologist reported the mammographic lesion found as BIRADS grade 2. What will be the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The management plan for this patient would be to undergo routine annual screening.

A Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of 2 means that it is a benign lesion, and for these patients, annual screening is advised.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy  ≥95% Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: A 62-year old woman was admitted for further management of a retrosternal goiter. CT imaging showed the goiter extending into the anterior mediastinum, beyond the sternum up to the superior aspect of the aortic arch. How is this case further managed?
questions.solution:
A retrosternal goiter that does not cross the superior aspect of the aortic arch can be resected via the standard transcervical thyroidectomy incision.

Most retrosternal goiters can be resected via standard cervical thyroidectomy incision since most are anterior and do not extend lower than the superior aspect of the aortic arch, on cross-sectional imaging. Proper neck extension, patient positioning, and a longer incision with mobilization of strap muscles improve access and help in the resection of the entire goiter.

Sternal split and partial or even total median sternotomy may be done in:

  • Malignant or revision cases
  • Extending into the posterior mediastinum
  • Extending below the aortic arch
  • Crossing the midline
  • When the diameter of the goiter exceeds that of the thoracic inlet

Thoracic surgery assistance is often needed for the more difficult substernal goiters requiring sternotomy or other mediastinal access.

In elderly patients with incidental retrosternal goiters, observation is preferred over treatment.

Substernal (or retrosternal) goiters include a significant proportion of the gland extending into the mediastinum through the thoracic inlet. 60% of cases occur among patients above 60 years of age. Subtypes of retrosternal goiter:

  • Extension into the anterior mediastinum, which is the most common.
  • Extension posteriorly to the great vessels, trachea, and/or recurrent laryngeal nerve, occasionally into the contralateral neck.
  • Isolated mediastinal goiter with no connection to the normal gland, receiving blood supply from the chest (least common)

Retrosternal goiters are associated with local compressive symptoms such as shortness of breath, orthopnea and dysphagia. This is due to the mediastinal extension of the gland which compresses the trachea, esophagus, and vascular structures within the thoracic inlet.

questions.text: Which of the following positions is best suited for surgeries of the posterior cranial fossa?
questions.solution:
Fowler's position or sitting position is best suited for posterior cranial fossa surgery. 

It is associated with a high risk of air embolism.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with long-standing diabetes presented with a gangrenous diabetic foot ulcer. Laboratory investigations are suggestive of septicemia. An X-ray of the foot shows bony erosion of the first and second metatarsals. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: After amputation, failure of take up of skin flap may occur
Intravenous antibiotics and wound debridement should be done
Amputation should be done distal to the gangrenous area
Revascularisation of the limb can be tried by angioplasty

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of diabetic gangrene of the right foot. The definitive management of patients presenting with gangrene and life-threatening systemic upset should be primary amputation. The level of amputation should be proximal to the area of gangrene.

A combination of three factors usually causes diabetic gangrene:

  • Ischaemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction
  • Peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy (PSN), which leads to trophic skin changes
  • Immunosuppression is caused by the excess of sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infection

Macrovascular disease is atherosclerotic and typically affects the crural vessels with relative sparing of the pedal vessels, whereas increased microcirculatory shunting causes microvascular dysfunction.

The peripheral neuropathy is usually sensory in the early phase, classically in a stocking distribution, and renders the patients at high risk of soft tissue injury and its subsequent neglect. It may extend to the foot and ankle joints, resulting in loss of nociceptive and proprioceptive protective reflexes and a repeated cycle of joint injury and bony destruction.

Motor involvement causes an imbalance between flexors and extensor muscle groups of the foot, promoting altered foot biomechanics and abnormal pressure loading and resulting in thick callosities developing on the sole of the foot.

Ischaemia and Peripheral neuropathy act synergistically to increase the risk of diabetic foot ulceration and reduce its subsequent healing potential. Superadded infection due to poor wound care can spread rapidly and proximally in subfascial planes leading to fulminant foot sepsis, gangrene, and death.

In dry gangrene, the separation occurs by aseptic ulceration with minimum infection and the gangrene is dry and mummified.

In wet gangrene, separation takes place by septic ulceration. Often demarcation is vague with skip lesions more proximally and so landing with a higher level of amputations. Even after amputation skin flap may show die back process, leading to failure of taking up of flap of amputation and so requiring a still higher level of amputation.

Treatment depends on arterial involvement, which should be investigated and treated rapidly with angioplasty or surgery. The gangrene is treated by drainage of pus, liberal debridement of dead tissue, and antibiotics. Unfortunately, a number of patients present with life-threatening systemic upset and should undergo primary amputation.

questions.text: All of the following serve as a landmark in the intra-op identification of facial nerve trunk by the anterograde method except:
questions.solution:
The parotid duct has the buccal branch of the facial nerve in close relation to it and can be used as a landmark for a retrograde method of facial nerve trunk location, not anterograde. 

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer: It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Squamotympanic fissure: It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process: The facial nerve lies superficial to it.
  • Mastoid process: Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch: It lies in relation to the parotid gland.
  • Marginal mandibular branch: It lies in relation to the facial vessels.
  • Temporal branch

questions.text: The phase of skin graft uptake in which the graft is most at risk for failure is:
questions.solution:
The phase of skin graft uptake during which the graft is most at risk for failure is the inosculation phase.

It is the phase in which the cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses. Graft failure during inosculation phase is due to mechanical shear, the formation of seroma or hematoma, or bacterial contamination. 

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink color of the skin.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Which is the most common feeding regime-related complication following total parenteral nutrition (TPN)?
questions.solution:
Hyperglycaemia is found in up to 50% of parenteral nutrition patients. Important predictors are insulin resistance or diabetes mellitus, severity of the underlying illness, concomitant steroid therapy, and the amount of glucose provided.

Complications of parenteral nutrition

Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypoglycaemia, hypocalcaemia
  • Hypophosphataemia & hypomagnesaemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: hyperglycaemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: hypercholesterolaemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridaemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcaemia, aminoacidaemia, uraemia

Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

Related to line

  • On insertion: pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydromediastinum
  • Long-term use: occlusion, venous thrombosis

questions.text: Which of the following is matched incorrectly with the knots in the image?
questions.solution:
The knot portrayed in image 4 is Granny's knot.

In the given image:

  1. Half-hitch knot
  2. Extra half-hitch on square
  3. Surgeon's knot
  4. Granny's knot

A granny's knot is a slip knot which is two throws of the same type. It is used to achieve the right tension and is followed by the reef knot for security. An Aberdeen knot is used for the final knot during continuous sutures. 

The surgeon's knot is a square knot that contains a double turn in the first throw. A "throw" is a complete twist of two strands in the square knot. The double turn makes the first throw of the surgeon's knot less likely to slip while the second throw is being tied. It is used when added security is required. A two-throw technique prevents slippage.

An image showing standard knotting formations is given below.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and bone pain. She had undergone total parathyroidectomy and heterotopic autotransplantation for the same complaints 8 months ago. A sestamibi scan was done and found to be normal. A Casanova test was done and was found to be positive. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent hyperparathyroidism. A positive Casanova test indicates that it could be due to recurrence in the neck or graft (graft hyperplasia).

The Casanova test involves selective venous sampling for PTH levels from neck veins and brachial veins. If PTH from the brachial venous sample is >20 times that of the neck vein sample, graft hyperplasia is confirmed.

Persistent parathyroid is defined as hypercalcemia that fails to resolve after parathyroidectomy i.e. within 6 weeks of surgery. Recurrent parathyroid is hyperparathyroidism that occurs after an intervening period of at least 6 months of biochemically documented normocalcemia.

Causes of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Ectopic parathyroid
  • Unrecognized hyperplasia - graft site hyperplasia
  • Missed adenoma in normal position
  • Incomplete resection
  • Familial hyperparathyroidism
  • MEN-1 syndrome

The image below summarizes the management protocol for a case of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism.

*FHH stands for Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed with high-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland. The patient is posted for radical parotidectomy. All of the following structures are removed except:
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid is not removed in radical parotidectomy.

Radical parotidectomy is indicated in patients with histological evidence of high-grade malignant tumors (mucoepidermoid tumor, squamous cell carcinoma) with facial nerve involvement. Low-grade malignant tumors are usually managed by superficial parotidectomy.

The structures removed in radical parotidectomy are:

  • The whole parotid gland
  • Dissection through the main trunk of the facial nerve
  • Ipsilateral masseter muscle
  • Neck node dissection of clinical, cytological and radiological lymph node metastases.

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.
