Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 34-year-old morbidly obese female patient was examined for thyroid swelling. The patient is asked to place the hands behind the neck and asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. This method is known as:
questions.solution:
In Pizzilo's method, the patient is asked to place their hands behind the neck and the patient is asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. It is used to inspect the thyroid gland more easily, especially useful in obese short-necked individuals. 

In Lahey's Method, the examiner stands in front of the patient and the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the right lobe medially by the left hand, and the left lobe is palpated with the right hand of the examiner.

The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules. This is known as Crile’s method.

Kocher’s test is done when one suspects pressure on the trachea. Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid causes stridor due to a narrow trachea. This test is positive in multinodular goitre and carcinoma infiltrating into the trachea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who was a chronic smoker came with complaints of swelling in the lip, as shown below. On examination, an ulcerative mass was seen and a submental lymph node was palpable. Which of the following is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Women above 60 years of age are commonly affected
Vermilion border of the upper lip is the common site
Exposure to chemicals like benzene is a common cause

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of lip cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men above 50 years of age. Exposure to the sun and smoking are the main risk factors of lip cancer. More than 90% of lip cancers are squamous cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip, followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. But the commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. The mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. There is a loss of sensation on the skin over the chin due to the involvement of mental nerves. Submental and submandibular nodes are frequently involved.

The early-stage disease can be treated by surgery or radiation therapy. Post-surgical irradiation is indicated in advanced-stage disease. For defects of more than one-third of the lip, surgical excision followed by lip augmentation surgery is needed.

questions.text: The operating surgeon inserted the following instrument after the exploration of  common bile duct. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kehr's T tube with the vertical and horizontal limbs.

Kehr's T tube is used after the exploration of common bile duct i.e. horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct and vertical limb is brought out as drain. It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimize the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal. However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones. some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

Option B: Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used to provide temporary hemostasis. It causes hemostasis by providing tamponade at the oesophagogastric junction.

Option C: Dobhoff tube is used for providing enteral nutrition.

Option D: Minnesota tube has 4 openings, 2 suction tubes, and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old diabetic patient with a frail build comes to the OPD. His wife is concerned about his recent weight loss and lack of appetite. Which parameters will you consider while assessing his malnutrition using MUST?
  1. Age
  2. Weight
  3. Height
  4. Recent weight loss
  5. Current nutritional intake
  6. Chronic illness
questions.solution:
Age and chronic illness are not a criterion used in MUST.

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) is a five-step screening tool to identify malnourished adults or adults at risk of malnutrition.

Related Pearl: Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST)

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool, ‘MUST’ is a five-step screening tool to identify adults, who are malnourished, at risk of malnutrition (undernutrition), or obese. It also includes management guidelines which can be used to develop a care plan.

questions.text: A surgery resident was applying hydrocolloid dressing to a patient's wound. What type of debridement is it?
questions.solution:
Hydrocolloid dressing is used in autolytic debridement.

Different types of debridement are as follows:

Surgical - excision of non-viable tissue using surgical instruments like scalpel, curette, or scissors until healthy bleeding occurs at the wound edges.

Mechanical - non-selective debridement as both non-viable and viable tissue may be removed, using irrigation, wet-to-dry dressings, and hydrotherapy.

Autolytic - using hydrocolloid dressings or transparent films to retain moisture and allow wound enzymes to liquefy non-viable tissue selectively.

Enzymatic - using topical agents like collagenase or papain-urea to chemically liquefy necrotic tissue with enzymes.

Biological - medical-grade larvae of Lucilia sericata release proteolytic and antimicrobial substances to remove necrotic tissue and promote wound healing directly.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.solution:
From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument. 

Electrosurgery is the use of high-frequency currents to cut or coagulate tissue during surgery. It can be performed using:

  • Monopolar or unipolar cautery: consists of a single electrode tip
  • Bipolar cautery: consists of two electrode tips in the form of scissors, graspers, etc. 

Other options

Option B: It is true that unipolar cautery can be used for coagulating tissue. The two main settings in unipolar and bipolar cautery are:

  • Coagulation mode: Blue button in the image above.
  • Cutting mode: Yellow button in the image above

In the coagulation mode, a high-voltage current is produced that spreads over a greater surface area. This helps to produce a dehydration effect on the tissues and is very useful when trying to stop the bleeding from nicked vessels during surgery. 

Option C: It is true, as mentioned above that unipolar cautery can be used for cutting tissue. Cutting mode produces a low voltage current that acts on a smaller surface area. This makes it more effective in heating the tissue than in the coagulation mode. The thermal spread will also be less than the coagulation mode, making it safer. 

Option D: It is true that monopolar cautery produces more thermal dissipation of current. 

The image below shows the unipolar and bipolar cautery-

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery:

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text:
Which of the following is a red flag for the selection of a patient for a day-care surgery?
  1. Low ACS NSQIP
  2. STOP-Bang score >4
  3. Metabolic syndrome
  4. OS-MRS >3

ACS NSQIP- American college of surgeons national surgical quality improvement program
OS-MRS - Obesity surgery mortality risk score
questions.solution:
2, 3 and 4 is the correct answer. STOP-BANG score >4, metabolic syndrome, and OS-MRS >3 are red flags for day-care surgery.

Daycare surgery is defined as the admission and discharge of a patient for a specific procedure within a 12-hour working day.

Red flags in the selection of a patient for daycare surgery are as follows:

  • Poor functional capacity
  • Abnormal ECG
  • Uncontrolled blood pressure, congestive cardiac failure, or ischemic heart disease
  • Oxygen saturation <94% on air
  • Bicarbonate >27mEq, suggestive of obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS)
  • Previous DVT/PE
  • STOP-Bang >4
  • OS-MRS >3
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • High ACS NSQIP risk

STOP-Bang is a questionnaire to screen patients for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

questions.text: A 5 year-old-boy was brought to the OPD by his parents with a painless swelling under the tongue. Which of the following statements is false about the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a mucous retention cyst from sublingual gland
On examination, both fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive
Definitive management is excision of the cyst
It is due to the obstruction of the duct of the sublingual salivary gland

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image point to a diagnosis of an oral ranula. It is a mucous extravasation cyst (not retention) arising from the sublingual gland. It is due to the obstruction of the duct of the sublingual salivary gland.

Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog.

It is of two types:

  • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managed by marsupialization. Definitive management is the excision of the cyst. Some may resolve spontaneously.
  • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes excision of the sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.

 Note: Oral ranulas located on the floor of the mouth can often be confused with an epidermoid cyst.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of a 2-cm parotid gland mass. It is reported as category III according to the Milan System for Reporting Salivary Gland Cytopathology. What does it signify?

choices.text: Salivary gland neoplasm of uncertain malignant potential (SUMP)

questions.solution:
Category III of the Milan System for Reporting Salivary Gland Cytopathology signifies atypia of undetermined significance (AUS).
